captions.text: It's perfectly obvious the time has a direction

All we mean by that is that the past is different from the future
in lots of different ways

We were younger in the past,
we will be older in the future

We remember the past,
we don't remember the future

The surprise is that that difference
between past and future

is nowhere to be found
in the deep down laws of physics

Time is actually a lot like space
if you're out in a space suit flying around

there will be no difference 
between up, down, left, right

likewise, there is no intrinsic difference
between the past and the future

in the laws of physics.
Now that's not completely a mystery to us

we know that what actually happens
in the real world

is that you're not just made of 
one or two particles

bumping into each other,
you're a very very complicated collection

of many many particles and
they're becoming more disorderly with time.
this is just saying that entropy increases.

The interesting thing is that every
difference between the past and the future

will utimately be traced to the fact that
the entropy was lower

in the past and is growing.
That's the Second Law of Thermodynamics

The universe was orderly,
it's becoming more disorderly

That's not a surprise. There is more ways
to be disorderly than to be orderly.

The suprise is that the universe was ever
low entropy to begin with.

If we go all the way back to the Big Bang,
13.7 billion years ago, the universe began

in a highly ordered state. So, modern
cosmologists are trying to understand

right now why the early universe was in
a such precise state.

why it was so low entropy.
Once we understand that,

it will make perfect sense to us
why the arrow of time stretches

as it does from the past to today
all the way toward the future.

Entropy is decreasing because the universe is expanding. The average

fluctuations temporarily decrease its entropy until they go away. If you 
are talking about a volume larger than the quantum scale, there are always 
an untold number of fluctuations at any time. They cause the average 
entropy to be slightly less than maximum. Provided that the volume is not

means the average entropy is slightly lower. And it increases the 
probability that a fluctuation will become a permanent change in the 
volume. In other words, the new, bigger volume has a lower entropy than 
when its started. Overall, entropy is decreasing in our universe.

The idea that the laws of physics are time symmetric is utterly wrong. 
While flipping the time coordinate (and possibly charge and parity as well) 
is a symmetry of every quantum field theory, the fact is the logical 
framework on which these theories are built is time asymmetric because the 
definition of probability is time asymmetric. You can only talk 
meaningfully about probabilities for physical processes in the context of a 
time asymmetric process of acquiring new information: you didn't know the 
position of this particle, now you do. 

If physicists stopped every once in a while to consider the philosophical 
assumptions underlying their theories they'd spend a lot less time worrying 
about meaningless questions such as the arrow of time.﻿

comments.text:
+hassi44 Entropy is a measure of the uncertainty in specifying the state of 
a system. If you think of a system (say, a rock) as being a collection of 
particles, then on a microscopic level, there might be a number of 
different ways those particles could be arranged. Unfortunately, even if 
you disregard quantum mechanics and the uncertainty principle, it isn't 
feasible to figure out the positions and momenta of all the individual 
particles— and why would you want to, anyway?
However, on a macroscopic level, you can measure the system's temperature, 
volume, pressure, amount of substance, etc., which constrains the number of 
microstates. For instance, if you know that the system is at 285 K, you can 
eliminate all the states that give you temperatures less than or greater 
than 285 K. At thermodynamic equilibrium, these properties are extremely 
close to special averages over the system's microstates, and they're what 
you're interested in anyway.
The entropy is a function of the probability distribution of microstates. 
Specifically,
S = -k_B*(p_1*ln(p_1) + p_2*ln(p_2) + ...)
where S is entropy, k_B the Boltzmann constant, and p_j the probability of 
the jth microstate AFTER you account for the known temperature, pressure, 
etc. Note that the more microstates there are and the lower their 
probabilities, the higher the entropy will be. That's because there's more 
information, or uncertainty, in the system's configuration.

comments.text:
+hassi44 According to Steinhardt--Turok model (the thing about branes 
colliding you hear about) branes just collide periodically. Although I must 
add a caveat: while string theorists are great at selling their stuff, they 
don't actually know enough about it to be of much use. In particular, 
nobody knows how to work out brane collision in such a model :)

Nevertheless, there is another cyclic cosmology that does kind of what you 
want: it's called the Baum--Frampton model. In this, expansion becomes so 
violent towards the end of the universe that a single tiny region that will 
become the next universe survives with zero entropy density. So the 
universe can then begin anew. It's cute and all, but I have a little 
reluctance to accepting the Big Rip hypothesis unless some actual data pins 
the behavior of dark energy more precisely. As far as we know right now, it 
could go either way: the universe could be ripped apart, or it could just 
fizzle out and suffer a heat death.

"One question though. Would it be possible, sometime in the future with the 
proper technology, to counter the deterioration of data compression? In 
physical systems that is."

No. The technology itself, whatever it is, must be itself bound by the 
second law, so while you might decrease the entropy locally on a physical 
system, when you consider the system *plus* your apparatus you'll find the 
entropy will have increased. This is actually a famous problem, known as 
Maxwell's demon. The idea is: you have a box with a gas and a partition in 
the middle. The partition has a little door, controlled by a demon which 
can magically measure positions and velocities of the gas' particles. The 
demon can then open the partition only for fast molecules moving from left 
to right, or for slow molecules moving from right to left. As time goes on, 
even though the demon exerted no work, you would see the temperature rise 
to the right of the partition. You can now hook up a heat engine to your 
system and extract useful work, making a perpetual motion machine of the 
second kind. Entropy has decreased. Or has it?

What Rolf Landauer discovered was that the entropy did not in fact decrease 
as long as you consider the Demon as part of your physical system. Then it 
becomes clear that any entropy loss is compensated by entropy gain on the 
demon's brain. Specifically, as long as you assume the demon has finite 
storage capacity, eventually he'll need to erase some information. The 
process of erasure is irreversible (in the thermodynamic sense) and so you 
don't get to extract thermal energy for free.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell%27s_demon

comments.text:
+hassi44 Hm, I'm not sure how to make that easier AND more concise at the 
same time. I think the JPEG analogy is valuable -- indeed, when computer 
scientists talk about data compression they also talk about information 
entropy -- and that's something that everybody understands intuitively this 
day and age. You compress an image, and you lose information in the 
process. I don't think it's much of a stretch to tell people that over time 
in physical systems your compression gets progressively worse and misses 
more of the internal information in the system. This is an accurate 
description, and it's also easy, but it takes more than just a few 
syllables :)

Really the most concise I can make it is to say that entropy is a 
measurement of how incomplete the experimenter's information about the 
system is, and the second law says that it can only get worse.

One very likely final fate for the universe is the so called "heat death" 
when all particles have decayed and you're left with a gas of nothing but 
the lightest stable particles in thermal equilibrium. When that happens, 
all the information in the universe (including, say, this conversation, 
every video on youtube, etc) will be inaccessible and a hypothetical 
meta-experimenter would have access only to pressure, density and 
temperature. Three numbers, whereas this conversation has significantly 
more than that. So there's a lot you can use to explain entropy and the 
second law, but overcoming the popular notion of order vs disorder will 
inevitably take some work.

comments.text:
+hassi44 It doesn't take anything special, really, to measure entropy in 
bits. The 'k' in the formula above is Boltzmann's constant. Its value is:

k = 1.3806488 × 10-23 m² kg/ (s² K)

The value isn't really important. It doesn't tell you anything about 
entropy or the universe; all it is is a unit conversion factor that depends 
on how big meters, kilograms, seconds and kelvin are. You could just as 
well choose units such that the numerical value of k would be exactly one, 
and indeed, particle physicists do this all the time. Then the formula for 
the entropy of a physical system at equilibrium (with some technical 
assumptions) will coincide with the formula for information entropy derived 
by Shannon. Except that Shannon's formula uses base-2 logarithms, not 
natural logarithms. No problem: just redefine your units again such that k 
= 1 / log 2, and then by the change of base formula now the logarithm is 
base 2, and the entropy will be given in bits. So measuring entropy in bits 
is no harder than measuring entropy in joules/kelvin: all it takes is a 
unit conversion, like changing between feet and meters.

Of course measuring entropy is not that easy in the first place since it 
requires that you know at least what the internal degrees of freedom *are*. 
You need to know how much you don't know. Not only is such a calculation 
incredibly cumbersome in practice, it's also hampered by the fact that we 
don't have access to the ultimate theory of physics so we can never be sure 
there's not a whole lot of other information hidden away, say, scribbled on 
the internal degrees of freedom of an electron if they exist. So even 
though you *can* write down a formula that relates the thermodynamic 
entropy to measurable things like the temperature or the pressure, that 
won't be the "real" entropy but merely a lower bound. This lower bound is 
often sufficient in practice though -- you don't care about the little 
quarks that make up protons if you're talking about hydrogen gas, for 
instance.

"One question though... Are you a physicist? Or a mathematician?"

I'm a physicist.

comments.text:
+hassi44 The definition of entropy is chiseled on Boltzmann's grave: 
http://schneider.ncifcrf.gov/images/boltzmann/P7140526.JPG

What this means is: let's say you have an isolated physical system in a 
certain state, in equilibrium. Say a gas. The true physical state of the 
gas is specified by the positions and velocities of every single molecule. 
We call this the microstate. However, this microstate is not experimentally 
accessible so we must characterize it by other aggregate variables such as 
the pressure, the temperature and the volume. This set of variables is 
called a macrostate. What this means is that we're performing some very 
lossy compression techniques on the state's information -- it's like a 
very, very bad jpeg of the gas. 

In other words, there will be very many microstates that correspond to a 
single macrostate, much like there are many different files that give the 
same CRC32 checksum. Let's say that W microstates correspond to a single 
macrostate. Then the entropy associated with the macrostate is given by the 
equation on Boltzmann's gravestone.

S = k log W

So the entropy of a macrostate is proportional to the logarithm of the 
number of microstates that correspond to that macrostate. It's a measure of 
how bad your information compression is. What the second law of 
thermodynamics states is that your compression can only get worse with time.

While people commonly say that entropy is disorder, that really is 
misleading since there are examples of highly ordered high entropy states. 
A black hole is one example: nothing in this universe can have a higher 
entropy per unit volume (indeed, the entropy of a black hole is 
proportional to its surface area which is surprising but a subject for 
another time), but it's just a featureless black sphere that can be 
completely characterized by three numbers: its mass, its electric charge, 
and its angular momentum.

No, it doesn't.
Think of it like this: I don't have to work to become a rotting corpse, but 
I do have to work to stay alive.
Order is just something you have to put energy into to maintain (work). The 
universe becomes more disordered over time simply because it's more likely. 
If I threw a deck of cards into the air, there are thousands of ways they 
could land out of order, but only one particular way they could all land in 
a neat deck, which is why you don't see it happen.
Similarly, if I didn't go through all the trouble of eating and my body 
didn't expend energy maintaining homeostasis, the matter making up my body 
would naturally fall apart if for no other reason than because it's easier; 
there are many, many ways something could go wrong and my body could come 
apart, and there are many, many other ways the matter could be arranged 
than it is currently, but only one specific configuration is "me". If I 
want to stay me, like this, I have to *constantly* expend energy so as to 
*constantly* keep all my parts working *a certain way*. And even then, I 
can't keep that up forever, it's just too much work.
On the other hand, if I just did nothing, then my body would fall apart 
without my having to work to make that happen. That's disorder; nothing's 
expending energy to keep the matter ordered any particular way.
Also, reorganizing isn't going back in time, because that reorganization 
will always only be temporary. I can expend energy to temporarily clean 
(order) a messy room, but that won't stop it from naturally becoming messy 
again. And I don't have an unlimited amount of energy to spend forever 
keeping that room from becoming disorganized. Chaos inevitably wins.

comments.text:
The *TOTAL ENTROPY* of an isolated system always increases, but an 
individual part of that system can *decrease* in entropy if some other part 
*increases* in entropy at least as much. 

That's what happens when you eat food and you get "energy" out of it. Your 
body is increasing in entropy, and if the entropy (i.e. disorder) gets too 
high, you'll die. But the chemical energy in food is "low entropy", and 
when you eat it, you *use* its increasing entropy to decrease your entropy, 
as long as the TOTAL entropy increases. Actually, that's basically how ALL 
machines work. When they burn furl or use electricity, they force its 
entropy to increase, and "use" that increase to decrease their own entropy, 
so that the total entropy still increases. 

As for the Earth, the Earth is not isolated. The sun is a giant nuclear 
fusion reaction, increasing in entropy by HUGE amounts every second, and 
it's sending huge amounts of "low entropy" light to Earth. This is how 
living things are able to grow, and even evolve, because the sun gives us 
all this "low entropy" energy. If there was no sun, then the Earth *would* 
just increase in entropy... plants would not get energy and they would die, 
then animals could not eat plants and they would die, then other animnals 
could not eat those animals and they would die, and eventually all sources 
of food and energy would run out, and everyone and everything would die, as 
the entropy just gets bigger and bigger and bigger.

comments.text:
I think the misconception might follow from the first law by separating 
heat from work then using heat to define entropy. Heat transfers due to 
temp differences are one source of entropy changes but there are others - 
mixing 2 different gasses for example - statistical mechanics bridges the 
gap between newton law and thermodynamics to provide accurate predictions 
about complicated systems. The second law is then a probabilistic statement 
which applies to everything, not just heat transfers.

of particles' locations result in outcomes determined in part simply by 
probability. Over time, the universe is to any given observer a mere result 
of one of the infinite possible ways in which the course of physics can 
play out. In other words, there is an infinite number of possible outcomes 
for the universe, each determined by a different, random course of the laws 
of physics. Every universe that can exist does exist.

It's often people hear that "time is only an illusion" but nobody actually 
stops and thinks the implications of what that means. Time is by its 
nature, made up in your own head. We create time by existing and thinking. 
Stimulus from the outside world influences our bodies, and get broken down 
and converted into complex chemicals that form chaotic and transient bonds 
within our brains. "Time" in reverse is your brain converting all of your 
memories and expelling them out into the universe.
